Getting started¶

Before starting the application, make sure all prerequisites are met and environment variables are correctly configured. Without this configuration, the project will not run properly.

Prerequisites¶

Secret Key¶

Django requires a secret key. If you don’t have one, you can generate a new one: Secret Key.

Sentry¶

The project uses Sentry for exception and error tracking.

  1. If you have not already created an account, go to: Getting started with sentry.

  2. Create a new Django project and follow instruction to configure it.

  3. Copy the provided DSN.

  4. You can find the DSN in your project settings under Project > Client Key.

Environment variables¶

To run, the project must find the following environment variables:

  • DJANGO_SECRET_KEY: Django signing key.

  • DJANGO_ALLOWED_HOSTS: Server addresses.

  • DEBUG: For debug mode, default is production mode. Activate with “True”.

  • DJANGO_SENTRY_DSN: DSN provided by Sentry.

Running the application¶

From repository¶

You must have completed the steps found in From repository.

  1. Open a terminal where your project is located (make sure your virtual environment is activated).

  2. Create an .env file containing the required environment variables, you can copy and modify .env.example.

  3. If you run the application with DEBUG=False, collect the statics:

    $ python manage.py collectstatic

  4. Start the application

    $ python mangage.py runserver

From Docker image¶

You must have completed the steps found in From image.

  1. Create an .env file containing the required environment variables, you can copy and modify .env.example.

  2. Make sure Docker is running.

  3. Run the container:

    With embedded database:

    $ docker compose -f docker-compose.demo.yaml up

    With volume:

    $ docker compose -f docker-compose.yaml up

The project will be accessible at: http://localhost:8000/
